feed.title: NewsTracker: snowden
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: News24.com | White House rejects petition to pardon Snowden
entry.summary:
Washington - The Obama administration has rejected a petition signed by almost 168 000 people calling on it to pardon former intelligence contractor Edward Snowden for leaking US government secrets.

"Edward Snowden is a national hero and should be immediately issued a full, free and absolute pardon for any crimes he has committed or may have committed related to blowing the whistle on secret NSA surveillance programmes," it said.

entry.title: Edward Snowden pardon petition rejected by US
entry.summary: In response to an online petition asking for a pardon for Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, a White House spokesman said on Tuesday that Mr Snowden should return to the United States and face justice.

entry.title: Edward Snowden pardon petition rejected by US
First Draft: U.S. Rejects Petition Seeking Pardon for Edward J. Snowden
entry.summary: The petition said Mr. Snowden was "a national hero and should be immediately issued a full, free and absolute pardon."

entry.title: White House: Snowden should face his consequences
White House: Snowden should face his consequences
entry.summary: "Mr. Snowden's dangerous decision to steal and disclose classified information had severe consequences for the security of our country and the people who work day in and day out to protect it," she said.

entry.title: NSA leaker Edward Snowden seeks return to US, on his terms
entry.summary:
Mr Snowden's release of classified files he took from his National Security Agency contractor's job blew the lid off programs long said to be aimed at catching terrorists and keeping Americans safe.

The journalists who were the conduits of Mr Snowden's disclosures have been bestowed with their profession's highest honors, as has director Laura Poitras with an Academy Award for her documentary on the fugitive, CitizenFour.

entry.title: NSA leaker Edward Snowden seeks return to US, on his terms
entry.summary:
Whistleblower Edward Snowden remains in hiding two years after the revelations.

But Mr Snowden has gained little more from his revolutionising disclosures beyond the sense of accomplishment he is said to feel, according to the few people in and outside Russia with whom he has occasional contact.

"Edward loves America and he would definitely like to return home," Anatoly Kucherena, Mr Snowden's Moscow lawyer, said in an interview at his ornate central Moscow office.

Sergei Markov, an ardent nationalist and Kremlin advisor on diplomacy and international affairs, said Mr Snowden was in need of Russia's protection because "he can compromise thousands of intelligence and military officials".

entry.title: German spy chief sees reason to thank Snowden
entry.summary:
BERLIN (AP) - Germany's domestic intelligence chief said Tuesday that the revelations by Edward Snowden have had at least one positive effect, by raising awareness about the importance of counter-espionage.

Although the reports didn't explicitly cite documents leaked to the media by Snowden, they came amid a flurry of similar claims about alleged U.S. surveillance in Germany that were linked to the former NSA contractor.

entry.title: German spy chief sees reason to thank Snowden
entry.summary: "So maybe one can be grateful to Snowden that he has put a spotlight on the issue of counter-espionage in Germany," dpa quoted Maassen as saying.

entry.title: Snowden documentary filmmaker sues US over years of harassment
Jeb Bush: No leniency for Edward Snowden
entry.summary: Holder told Yahoo that Snowden's actions "spurred a necessary debate" about the bulk collection of phone records and that the U.S. was "in a different place" as a result.

entry.title: Ex-attorney general Holder says DOJ could strike a deal with Snowden
entry.summary: After the disclosure, Holder led a crackdown on government leakers, including charging Snowden with three felony violations of the Espionage Act for turning over thousands of government documents to journalists.

entry.title: Justice Dept. could strike deal with Edward Snowden upon US return - Eric Holder
entry.summary: Melanie Newman, chief spokeswoman for Attorney General Loretta Lynch, Holder's successor, immediately shot down the idea that the Justice Department was softening its stance on Snowden.

entry.title: Edward Snowden plea deal with US a possibility, says Eric Holder
entry.summary: "This is an ongoing case so I am not going to get into specific details but I can say our position regarding bringing Edward Snowden back to the United States to face charges has not changed," Melanie Newman said in an email.

entry.title: Holder sees possible DOJ deal with Snowden
entry.summary: "We are in a different place as a result of the Snowden disclosures."
